alert.note: Alert for Henderson (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 23 at 11:17PM EDT until March 24 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 245 AM EDT THURSDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Central and eastern Henderson County, North Carolina. * WHEN...Until 245 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor Flooding along Mud Creek and high flows along the Green River are expected. Nuisance to Minor flooding along the Green River is possible. * At 10.0 feet, Mud Creek may be overtopping the S. Grove St bridge deck and inundating S. Grove St adjacent to the bridge. The railroad tracks adjacent to S. Grove St are likely overtopped by floodwaters spilling onto E. Caswell St. Mud Creek is approaching the underside of the bridge deck at Erkwood Dr with flooding along Erkwood Dr likely. Significant farmland flooding is ongoing within a 5-mile reach up and downstream from the Erkwood Dr. gauge site, and may be impacting several outbuildings and farm structures. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1058 PM EDT, Periods of moderate to heavy rain over the past 24 hours has resulted in 2-4 inches of storm-total rainfall across Henderson County, with localized totals exceeding 5 inches within the headwaters of Mud Creek and the Green River. This has caused excessive runoff and significant stream rises across much of Henderson County, but especially within the Mud Creek and Green River watersheds. Minor flooding is ongoing and additional Minor flooding is likely to develop over the next 1-3 hours before area streams crest and begin to recede later overnight. Minor flooding is defined as flooding of parks, greenways, farmland, nurseries, woodlands, and low-water crossings up to 2-4 feet deep as well as inundation of secondary roads and campgrounds up to 1-2 feet deep. Mud Creek is above the Minor Flood Stage of 8.5 feet at 9.2 feet. Moderate Flood Stage is 10.0 feet. Mud Creek`s rate of rise is slowing and a crest may be imminent; however, it is likely Mud Creek will approach 9.8-10.0 feet before cresting over the next 2-4 hours. A reasonable worst-case crest of 10.5 feet is possible. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hendersonville, Flat Rock, Mountain Home, Laurel Park, Dupont State Forest, Jones Gap State Park, Chimney Rock State Park, Valley Hill, East Flat Rock, Dana, Tuxedo, Crab Creek and Edneyville. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
